description: Machine learning dataset for automated theorem proving. Predicts which of five heuristics will give the fastest proof when used by a first-order prover, with a sixth option to decline attempting a proof if the theorem is too difficult.
source: UCI Machine Learning Repository / University of Cambridge
creator: James P. Bridge, Sean B. Holden, Lawrence C. Paulson (University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory)
feature_description: Mixture of static and dynamic features derived from theorems to be proved, including structural properties, complexity measures, and syntactic characteristics of first-order logic formulas

target_values.6: Theorem too difficult - decline to prove

use_case: Automated theorem proving, heuristic selection for proof search, machine learning for mathematical reasoning, optimization of theorem provers
data_collection: Features extracted from first-order logic theorems, with performance data from running different heuristics on a theorem prover
mathematical_background: First-order logic theorem proving using resolution-based methods with different search heuristics
challenges: Complex feature engineering required, difficulty in capturing logical structure, heuristic performance may vary with prover implementation
advantages: Enables intelligent heuristic selection, improves theorem prover efficiency, bridges machine learning and automated reasoning
research_impact: Demonstrates application of machine learning to improve automated reasoning systems
ethical_considerations: Automated reasoning systems should be transparent about their limitations and not replace human mathematical verification for critical applications

citations.author: James P. Bridge, Sean B. Holden, Lawrence C. Paulson
citations.title: Machine learning for first-order theorem proving: learning to select a good heuristic

original_source.creator: James P. Bridge, Sean B. Holden, Lawrence C. Paulson (University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory)
original_source.institution: UCI Machine Learning Repository / University of Cambridge
original_source.publication: James P. Bridge, Sean B. Holden, Lawrence C. Paulson: Machine learning for first-order theorem proving: learning to select a good heuristic

dataset_history: Data Collection: Features extracted from first-order logic theorems, with performance data from running different heuristics on a theorem prover
inference_notes: Challenges: Complex feature engineering required, difficulty in capturing logical structure, heuristic performance may vary with prover implementation.
